citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
**While inspecting the barn housing llamas, alpacas, donkeys and a camel, it was noted that one of the llama/alpaca
crosses had an area of hair loss on it's back measuring approximately 2 cm x 3 cm. The licensee had not noticed the hair
loss on this animal. Daily observations of the animals should be routinely made in order to ensure potential health issues
are promptly communicated to the attending veterinarian so that appropriate treatment can be provided as deemed
necessary.
Correct by April 11, 2023

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
** A copy of the Program of Veterinary Care was not available for review at the time of inspection. The licensee indicated
the Program of Veterinary Care had recently been reviewed but had not been returned by the Attending Veterinarian. A
copy of the updated and current Program of Veterinary Care should be maintained at the facility and available for review
by APHIS officials during the unannounced visits as set forth in this section.
Correct by April14, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
**A written environmental enrichment program for the non-human primates was not available for review during the
inspection. The licensee is providing environmental enrichment for the animals, however, was unable to provide a plan
that had been reviewed and approved by the attending veterinarian. A written environmental enrichment plan that has
been reviewed and approved by the attending veterinarian should be maintained and followed by the facility in order to
promote the psychological well-being of the non-human primates.
Correct by April 20, 2023

**The interior areas in the building housing several coatimundis, porcupines and kinkajous did not have adequate lighting.
The interior of the building and enclosures had dim lighting which does not allow to adequately view the flooring, interior
surfaces or the animals. Poor quality lighting does not allow for proper cleaning of enclosures and visualization of
animals. Indoor housing facilities should have ample lighting that is of good quality in order to allow for routine cleaning
and visualization of the animals as set forth in this section.
Correct by April 24, 2023

**Excessive flies were noted in the primate kitchen area. Fly strips were in the kitchen, however, the strips were full of
flies. Numerous flies in the kitchen area indicates poor husbandry practices. An effective pest control program is
necessary to ensure effective husbandry practices are being maintained in order to promote the welfare of the animals.
Correct by April 14, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
